description:
Salminus brasiliensis, commonly known as the dorado or golden dorado, is a freshwater fish species found in the major river basins of South America, particularly in the Paran√°, Paraguay, and Uruguay river systems. It is a member of the family Characidae, which includes various species of tetras and characins.

The dorado is a medium to large-sized fish, typically reaching lengths of up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) and weighing up to 20 kilograms (44 pounds). It has a streamlined, torpedo-shaped body and a large, terminal mouth with sharp teeth, adaptations that make it an effective predator. The species is known for its vibrant golden-yellow coloration, which has earned it the nickname "golden dorado."

Salminus brasiliensis is an important sport and commercial fish, valued for its strong fighting behavior and excellent table qualities. It is a voracious predator, feeding primarily on smaller fish, crustaceans, and aquatic insects. The species plays a significant ecological role in its native habitats, serving as a top predator and contributing to the overall balance of the riverine ecosystems.

Due to factors such as habitat degradation, overfishing, and the construction of dams, the conservation status of Salminus brasiliensis is a matter of concern in some regions. Efforts are underway to better understand the biology and ecology of this species, as well as to implement effective management strategies for its sustainable utilization and conservation.
